This week's green tip: How to save your wallet and the environment by cutting water consumption
One can save both the environment and the wallet by reducing water consumption at home.
07 Nov 2019, 09:45 by Ingrid Emilie Thoresen Bakker
Background: Through a series of articles, we give consumers tips and tricks for living greener lives. No index fingers, only information.
The experts: Thomas Breen and Christian Vogelsang.
Jobs like: The former is a director of the trade organization Norsk Vann. Vogelsang is a researcher at the Norwegian Institute of Water Research (NIVA).
Each Norwegian uses 180 liters of water a day
- The largest water consumption in ordinary households is related to personal hygiene, ie bathing, showering and toilet flushing, says Vogelsang.
Recently, there has been a general decline in water consumption, he says. Probably because you have been given washing machines, showers and toilets with water-saving programs.
Nevertheless, each Norwegian uses an average of 180 liters of water every day, according to statistics from Statistics Norway for 2018. That is almost twice as much as the Danes.
So many of us probably have a bit to go on when it comes to water consumption. But does it really have an impact on your wallet or the environment?
Yes, experts believe.


- We can advantageously have a conscious relationship with our own water consumption, both during hot periods in the summer and otherwise in the year. And it's easy to save water, says Thomas Breen.üì∑ Arnfinn Johnsen


This week's green tip: The laundry that saves the environment and gives you better time

12 tips for limiting water consumption

You consume much less water and energy by showering shorter and less frequently than by filling a bath with several hundred liters of hot water.
Mount the spare shower. Then you only use half as much (hot) water.
Do not put on a washing or dishwasher until it is completely full. Then you save water, energy and detergent.
Repair dripping water taps.
Do not allow the water to drain while brushing your teeth.
Installing toilets with a water-saving flush button has become more and more common. Use the "save button" whenever possible.
Wash the car at a car wash. There you normally use less water than you do at home.
It can be a lot of water to save on not watering the lawn as it goes at about 1000 liters per hour.
Water flowers and shrubs with jug.
If you notice a lot of condensation on the water pipes in the basement, it could mean, for example, the toilet is running. As much as 400,000 liters of clean water a year can be lost through a cistern running. Immediately repair any damage or contact the plumber for further investigation.
If you have reduced water pressure in the home or hear whistling in the pipes even if no water is used, there may be indications of leakage on the outside mains. This can lead to large water losses. If you suspect this, you should contact the operating department of the municipality or a private company that can conduct leak detection.
Occasionally check the water meter when no water is being used, and check if the meter is completely still. If it does not, it will stand water and flow somewhere.


This week's green tip: Four products you can use instead of plastic wrap



Today we get transported all the household waste to large central treatment plants, which purify the water and discharge it to a depth, so that it will not end up on beaches or could give rise to algae blooms. - The necessary water quality requirements are required before the water is released into the deep or used in agriculture on land, says researcher Christian Vogelsang at NIVA.üì∑ NIVA

Therefore, you should avoid wasting water
Here's why:
- Household wastewater, must be transported in wiring and cleaned at the wastewater treatment plants. The more water we use, the more chemicals and energy that goes into transporting and producing clean drinking water, Thomas Breen explains.
In addition, the used water could affect the environment where it is discharged. Micro-contamination, which occurs, among other things, as a result of residues of medicines and personal care products, can do great harm, explains Vogelsang.
Can you reduce your water fee?
The tap water is not free. For example, a drip crane that has one drip per second will use 9 cubic meters per year (m¬≥). On the other hand, a running crane with about 2 millimeters beam will use 45 cubic meters per year.
When leaking in the toilet, it can go between 100 and 400 cubic meters a year. It can get expensive.
- It is the subscribers themselves who have to pay for the water they use. Therefore, it is not only an advantage for the environment, but also for the wallet that we do not waste water, says Breen.
He emphasizes that the possibility of a reduced water fee only applies if you have installed water meters and are billed according to what you actually use.
